Problem:
Consider a complex function \\(z(t) = e^{i\\omega t}\\), where \\(i\\) represents the imaginary unit and \\(\\omega\\) is a constant frequency. We investigate how transformations defined by the integral transformation \\(T[f](t) = \\int_{0}^{t} e^{\\alpha s} f(s) \\, ds\\), with constant \\(\\alpha\\), affect the function over time t.

Having observed the outcome of the transformed function \\( T[z](t) \\) at t = T, can we precisely determine the original function \\( z(t) \\) at t = 0?
Explanation: The integral transformation modifies the function in such a way that it integrates all prior influences of both the exponential term and the original function up to time t. This accumulation means the exact original state at any earlier time, specifically t = 0, cannot be confidently reverse-engineered solely from knowing \\( T[z](t) \\) at t = T without additional information about \\(\\omega\\) and \\(\\alpha\\).
